Interesting is 11 B-N2 B-N2 12 KR-K1 P-N4 13 N-Q5?! PxN 14 PxP K-B1 15 N-B5 R-B1, and Black won (Bernstein-Fischer, 1957-8 US Championship.)
Giving up the K5 square in order to exert pressure on K6.
Giving up the K5 square in order to exert pressure on K6.
Vladimir Simagin gave this move a "?" and proceeded to analyze the alternative 12... P-N5 13 PxP PxN 14 PxN ch BxP 15 P-K5, etc. By this logic the whole variation is unsound for Black.

Tigran Petrosian and Mikhail Tal happened to stroll by the board at this instant. Petrosian made a wry face which looked to me like "Can Black do this and live?" But if Black tries 13... B-Q2, on 14 P-N5! PxNP 15 PxP PxP 16 NxP Black's game collapses.
